dcsl_state_estimator Documentation

dcsl_state_estimator: dcsl_state_estimator

The dcsl_state_estimator package contains dcsl_miabot_state_estimator node and dcsl_miabot_estimator_math library. The purpose of this package is to provide an extended Kalman-Bucy filter that takes in state measurements and control inputs to estimate the current poses of the differential-drive Miabots in the system.

  • Homepage: http://ros.org/wiki/dcsl_state_estimator

dcsl_state_estimator

This package provides state estimation for planar differential drive robots, using an extended Kalman-Bucy filter for continuous dynamics with discrete measurement updates.

ROS API

List of nodes:

  • dcsl_miabot_state_estimator.cc

List of libraries:

  • dcsl_miabot_estimator_math.h

List of tests:

  • miabot_estimator_math_test.cc

dcsl_miabot_state_estimator

This node estimates the states (poses) of the robots based on incoming measurements from the vision tracker and control inputs from the low level controller. States are propagated and estimates published at a rate of at least 25 Hz (with more depending on rate of measurements).

Usage

$ dcsl_miabot_state_estimator [standard ROS args]

ROS topics

Subscribes to (name / type):

  • "planar_measurements/PoseArray" : contains array of poses of robots as measured by vision tracker.
  • "cmd_vel_array/TwistArray" : contains array of Twists describing velocity of each robot.

Publishes to (name / type):

  • "state_estimate/PoseArray" : array "poses" holds estimate of current pose for each robot.

ROS parameters

  • "/n_robots" : Number of robots to be controlled.
  • "initial_poses" : List of initial positions of robots in the system, in the format [x_0, y_0, theta_0, x_1, y_1, theta_1, ...].

dcsl_miabot_estimator_math

This is a C++ shared-object library that includes the math functions used in the state estimator. It depends on the Eigen linear algebra library for matrix computations.

dcsl_miabot_state_estimator_test

Unit tests for the dcsl_miabot_estimator_math library using the Google gtest framework. (A work in progress...)

To compile and run, from within the package folder type: 

$ make tests
$ make test
